text:
A little bit hoppier than your average marzen. An Oktoberfest with a Lagunitas twist on it. 

Reviewed - A Brew With You, Ep. 54
Orange pour. Aroma is malt and floral notes. Flavor is sweet malt, pepper and floral notes. Some warmth. Not your Dads marzen:) okbyme
Bottle from Craft. Hazy coppery pour with frothy, off-white head. Nose was earthy copper malt, hops, woody notes. Tasted like a more earthy and woody red IPA.

3/5/17. 12oz bottle from Habersham. Caramel colored pour with a really nice khaki head. Sweet malty aroma, caramel, some nuttiness and earthiness. Somewhat sweet malty flavor, caramel, earthy, husks. Not bad.
Bottle. Good take on a style I generally dont dig. Clear reddish orange pour with a white head. Malty sweetness. Herbal and floral hops.

12oz bottle. Deep copper amber body. Foamy off-white head. Big malt depth, pleasant new school soft hop balance. Full bodied to almost approach Doppelbock, but has some amber malt and filtered Oktoberfest sensibility. Solid offering.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a vibrant red-orange-caramel color with a large foamy orange-white head that left good lacing. The aroma was sweet with honey, toffee, faint fruity hops and orange marmalade. The flavor was sweet and malty with toffee, honey, faint orange marmalade and fruity hops. Medium length finish. Medium bodied and smooth. Solid.

Bottle: Cleap copper color with medium head and great lace. Caramel aroma with some hops. Citrus an tropical fruit. Refreshing lift. Big and rich beer. Some freshness and a bitter finish. Palate is a balance of malt and hops. 
This beer has me confused. Cant determine if Im a fan or its just ok.

Dark amber color with a thick head of cream colored foam. Sweet cereal grain, light caramel and candied citrus in the aroma. Clean, sweat bread and caramel malt with sweet citrus on the palette. Nice bit of gusto for a lager.

From the 12 fl. oz bottle with no date that I can see. Medium amber, heady pour into the mug. The aroma is subtle with caramel malts, a little soapiness, and a little grass. The body is medium to full. The taste is a letdown from the aroma but it may be due to being old. I got something soapy with the caramel malts but a mild to moderate resiny bitter finish helped rescue it some. I wish I had it in October.
12oz bottle. Poured an amber color with a small sized off white head. Caramel, toasted nutiness, and some bread.

12 oz bottle, thanks brenn79. Aroma is old malt, grain, caramel, herbal, freshly chopped wood. Pours clear copper with a thick long-sustaining cream-colored head that leaves splotchy lace. Taste is malty sweet, finishing with a nice herbal hop bitterness. I wish I had tried this fresher. Seems like it would be a cut above if it was fresher. Unique take, for sure.

12oz bottle from Kenny Road Market: copper-orange pour, medium eggshell head. aroma is caramel malt. tastes toasty and sweet bready malt, earthy, light spice, background citrus, moderate bitter knocks back sweetness. not a fan of the style, but pretty tasty.

12 oz bottle- Pours chestnut amber with a bubbly off white head. Aroma is caramel malts, toffee, toast, a bit of peppercorn spice. The taste is caramel malts, toffee, there is a bit of cocoa in here. Not bad.

Bottle. It poured a cloudy amber color with a white head. The aroma was of malts, herbs and pine. The taste was similar to the aroma with more malts, herbs, pine, biscuits and some herbs. The hops are subtle, but still a nice drinkable beer.
Fun to try a potato beer. Leans sweet...but lots of fruit aroma and taste. $2.39 per 12 ounce bottle.

Deep and dark orange, like prunce juice. You dont see a ton of these kinds of dark ales all that much these days. It looks like a TRUE Oktoberfest.

Aroma is very sugary. Heavy raisin/prune component. A touch of plastic/phenols but that may be due to an Oktoberfest being consumed in January. 

The flavor is very sweet and sugary, but with a bitter-cherry end. There is a surprising hop that adds a nice, mild woody complexion. 

A creamy, chewy finish. Its a good, malt-forward "change of pace" beer among the hop bombs and sours you tend to see. The sugary aspects of it are well-balanced to prevent it from being a malt bomb.
Bottle. Deep amber with one finger head. Pretty substantial body for the style. Caramel and toffee. Sweet potato and brown sugar. Substantial hops. Verging on overdone, but it works.

12 oz bottle poured. A copper color with a rocky, patchy head. An inviting aroma of caramel malts, and quite bold. Flavor is a huge toasty malt. Bold and roasted. A bit odd. I expected more of a hop impression here, but the malt is very powerful. As weird as I think it is, it still drinks easily. A sweet caramel linger. Strange, but not bad.

12 oz single bottle from Hy Vee Wine & Spirits - Muscatine. Clear amber appearance with a lingering tan head. The aroma is malty, nutty and toasty with light caramel/toffee and light fruity esters. Similar flavor, adding moderate malt sweetness and light hop bitterness. OK.

APPEARANCE-litght amber w orangish hue. Great thick head. 
NOSE-nicly hopped for just a touch of hop scent. And some earthy, malty tones prevail. 
FLAVOR- exceptionally smooth. Slight unique aftertaste. No discernable hop flavor and the malt isnt overbearing. Its just a clean, smooth drinking beer. 
NOTES- unique beer. I havent read what style it is, and I cant put my finger on exactly what style. I like it.

Bottle at Total Wine & More, St Petersburg. Dark amber, clear without much visible carbonation. Small bit of white head. Grass and sumptuous resin in the aroma. Taste is more bitter and slightly medicinal - albeit with a strong malt base - leading to a strong bitter finish. Bitter herbs in the aftertaste. Nicely flavoured and with a good balance.

12 ounce bottle from Whole Foods Milwaukee, 10/9/16. Clear red-copper, large foamy tan head, good retention. Aroma of earthy, caramel, toffee, lemon. The taste is caramel, toffee, lemony hops, a bit of earthiness. Medium bodied, well balanced.
nice grass hop aroma. taste is a bitter malt and hop blend with some caramel.

12.15.2016 - bottle from Whole Foods.  Nose is earthy hops and pleasant spice/herbs. Palate balanced with lively piney hops and smooth (but not overly creamy) earthiness. High carbonation and doesnt get to that putrid level of graniness that seems to be incumbent upon all holiday/Oktoberfest brews once you are 60% of the way through the bottle. Really enjoyed.

Bottle. Nice, pure amber pour, with a solid head and great lacing. The aroma is amazing, full of grain and goodness (most American hop geeks would argue with me, Im sure). This is also a fully-flavored, malty brew, with a rich baseline, and a distinctively American hoppiness artfully intermingled. (#6459, 12/14/2016)

Bottle. Pours clear orange-copper with a lasting disc of beady foam. Nose is big with toffee, spicy resin, tea, citrus and a touch of toasted nut. Flavors of orange toffee, grassy hops and toasted nut. Medium-plus body has a smooth, low-medium carbonation and a nice balance.

Bottle. Milky caramel malt and cedar aroma. Dark amber with nice light tan head. Moderate sweet/lightly acidic nutty caramel malt and mildly bitter herbal hay/cedar flavor. Good body.   Pretty good, on the sweet side.

Sample sent for review, notes from September 2016. My pour presents a deep amber body with a very stiff and persistent white head. There is a big amber malt smell to it, and the usual boatload of hops, definitely a Pacific Northwest with its citrusy and piny note, theres also some Northern Brewer which gives it the rough hop smell and taste of a California common lager. Theres a full bodied crystal or Vienna malt presence that remains in conflict with the excess hops, as you would expect from a West Coast brewer. Despite that, and its 7.5% abv, it can go down pretty quickly.
As with the Surly Fest I sampled last weekend, this is another American beer that takes the basic concept of an Oktoberfest beer and runs wild with it. You can finish up your Oktoberfest celebratory evenings with this, but youll surely want to lay down a base of more traditional beers in the style to start and make this kind of the desert.

Bottle from The Lazy Dog
Deep copper color with a huge bubbly beige head that persists forever. Orange and burnt caramel on the nose mostly. Smells like a 90s IPA kind of. Sweet kind of syrupy with a deep sticky caramel and orange citrus hops. Doesnt really work for me.

Pour is a clear copper with a large white head. Aroma is a typical bready malt with some faint whiff of hops. Flavor is a heavy biscuit malt with a slight hop and some toffee and dark fruit. A bit heavy for the style but I like the attempt of making a hoppy marzen. A bit thinner malt bill and a bit more hops and you may have something.

bottle @ Party Town / Florence KY --- Aroma of pine hops. Clear amber brown color, ivory head that stays at a thick cover. sheets of lace. Taste is slightly bitter malt that adds light hops, then speeds through a somewhat short finish. Its serviceable, but not up to the 7.5% abv.
on tap at Dog & Bull in Croydon - cool amber color. Not much aroma. Interesting spicy/sweet/malty flavor.

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, dark orange-red pour with thin off white head, aroma brought notes of grapefruit, caramel, toffee, hints of herbal, floral notes with a hint of grass. Taste was a mix of mint, grass, herbal notes, touch of orange, a bit of caramel, toffee, finishing slightly bitter. Just not my thing.
Bottle. Copper beer with a dark cream head. Light spice and malt aroma. Malt and spice flavor. Medium bodied. Spice and malt lingers.
Clear copper, with a bunch of thick white foam. Smells like caramel and pine, plus some black pepper. Nicely smooth palate. Taste is pretty much the same as the aroma, maybe a little more peppery.

Clear copper color with nice lacy white head. Sweet malty aroma with some hop balance. Flavor is moderately sweet, clean with a nice (light) earthy hop balance. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

An interesting twist on Oktoberfest beer. Far more hoppy without the sweetness of your typical Oktoberfest offering. Pours a wheat color without much going on. The nose is slightly hoppy with floral overtones. A nice change of pace seasonal!

Clear bronze pour with a large beige head and excellent retention. Decent lacing. Nose of floral hops. Taste is a strange mix of spicy hops and malt. Fail on both fronts. This isnt a good German or American Oktoberfest beer; This a screwed up APA for hops lovers.

Poured from the tap into a tulip glass at Taco Mac in Atlanta. The appearance is a copper color with some brown tossed in. With a medium sized off-white head. The aroma is pine and malt. The taste is very close to the nose.

Pours a reddish-brown with a thin head. Aromas of resinous hops and caramel overlaid with faint notes of liquorice and mint, and distant hint of boiled veg. Smooth and dry-sweet, with more caramel balanced by firm hoppy bitterness and drying alcohol. A hopped-up potato Märzen - whatever next!?

Pours a clear rather dark amber with a respectable off white head. Aroma is honey, malt and spicy hops. Taste is sweet caramel malt, buttered biscuits, honey and perhaps a slight bit more hoppiness than youd expect from the style. Nevertheless, a quality Oktoberfest style effort.

Clear amber, fluffy orange head. Full body, flavorful, silky, hot and well carbonated mouthfeel, lingering and tasty aftertaste. Bittersweet, well balanced. Very hoppy, like an IPA, rich malt, citrusy, orange peel. Delicious, the best ocktoberfest I ever had, if this is an ocktoberfest. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Light malt and spice smell, taste is smooth and spicy...like coriander and darker malts, flying saucer with john
Pretty sessionable considering its higher abv for the style. Very rich and sweet, with burnt caramel malt and brown sugar notes above hints of smoke and molasses. Medium length.

$2.35 bottle from Wine Warehouse, Pours burnt orange with a good-sized soft beige head. Aroma is caramel malt, citrus, pine. Flavor is caramel, licorice, pine, malty. Theres something in this beer I just dont like. Reminds me a bit of a long-ago puke. Its not that bad... but I dont like it.
Bottle from Liquor Barn. Pours a hazy copper. Nice blend of hops and malts.

Bottle picked up at France 44 and consumed on Election Night from a Belgian Moeder Lambic glass. Pours an attractive amber/copper color with a slightly off white/tannish head. Nice lacing. Nose has traditional Oktoberfest/marzen malty caramel notes but incorporates more hops than others. Reinforces the fact this is coming from Lagunitas. Taste has a nice bite with a piney quality but the predominant flavor is coming from a malty caramel/toffee characteristic. Feels very much like a West Coast hopped Oktoberfest which is basically what I think the brewery was trying to create. Finishes with some sweetness with a full mouthfeel. A very enjoyable beer for the autumn season.

Tap - average size foamy head, nice medium Amber color, string caramel malty aroma and flavor with a good earthy hop balance, fairly spicy finish, pretty complex for an Oktoberfest style beer, very good overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle pour into taster cup at One Stop Market 30th Anniversary. Appearance is medium brown/orange. Aroma is cracker and biscuit malts, with slightly richer caramel as well. Taste is richer malts than traditional cracker/biscuit, also with hoppier contribution (go figure with Lagunitas). Palate is medium bodied with average carbonation and finish like taste. Overall, a little richer, fuller malt contribution than the standard Marzen and extra hops, too.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a thick, gradually collapsing, ivory head, with moderate lacing, over a clear, light copper (SRM 17) body........nose is pine, resin, light citrus, from the hops, mild toasted malts with cracker, bread tones, balance to the hops.......taste is mildly sweet, with light florality, mild malts, from the hops pine, resin, citrus with orange and grapefruit notes, finishing with moderate bitterness, balance to the hops.....mouth feel, slightly sticky, light of medium body, slight alcohol high carbonation. Idaho number seven was introduced in 2015 and gives the types of aromas and flavors noted. The malts, while pleasant are rather understated for the style, and the alcohol is too high.The result is a beer that misses the Oktoberfest/Marzen style greatly because of the hops, malts and alcohol.. The beer is quite clean, nicely complex and easy to enjoy. Above score to enjoyment, below to style accuracy. BJCP 5/3/10/4/5

Strong, juicy citrus/pine hop aroma from a crystal clear medium amber body with a foamy white head. This follows into the taste which is very IPA-like and not like an Oktoberfest. Nice roasted wood and caramel sweetness comes out after this to balance the bitterness. Finishes sweet and bitter with a long woody after taste.
Slightly rancid malt aroma. Clear amber color with a small white head. Moderate sweet beginning with a vinegar bitter finish.

I had a feeling this was going to be really bad and I was right. Kudos to me for being an idiot and buying it anyway. Anyway, as expected, this is thick and sticky, way too hoppy for the style and the wrong hops anyway. All of this I expected but I did not expect the odd unfinished wortiness and harsh, weird woody bitterness. Lagunitas is normally pretty solid on their too sweet hoppy beers but this is an exception. It is kind of a tour de force of out-of-place dank, hoppy grossness and residual sugars being where actual malt character should be. Overall, this beer can take a fucken hike.

12 ounce bottle into dimpled mug, bottled on 9/21/2016. Pours crystal clear deep orange/copper color with a 1-2 finger dense light khaki head with good retention, that reduces to small cap that lingers. Nice spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of big grapefruit, peach, pineapple, apricot, papaya, mango, melon, orange peel, light pepper, pine, caramel, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, light nutty/toffee, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of citrus/tropical/pine hops and moderate dark/bready malt notes; with great strength. Taste of big grapefruit, peach, pineapple, apricot, papaya, mango, melon, orange peel, light pepper, pine, caramel, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, light nutty/toffee, herbal, and floral/grassy earthiness. Light-moderate pine/herbal/spicy bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, peach, pineapple, apricot, papaya, mango, melon, orange peel, light pepper, pine, caramel, brown sugar, toasted biscuit, and herbal/floral/grassy earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/tropical/pine hops and moderate dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/bitterness balance, and zero astringent hop flavors after the finish. Light-moderate dryness from bitterness, increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready/sticky, and slightly resinous balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol for 7.5%. Overall this is a great hoppy Oktoberfest style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of citrus/tropical/pine hops and moderate dark/bready malt flavors; very smooth and easy to drink. Feels really juicy on the hops, with a nicely balanced Munich malt backbone; never feels too bitter or sweet. A very enjoyable offering.

This is a fantastic Oktoberfest-style beer! The lone bottle I had of it did not last very long! The Tuberfest poured a rich, dark orange color with a brown hue. The head was beige, soft, pillowy and laced beautifully around the glass. The first thing in the aroma that stuck out to me was the hops. At that point I knew this beer was gonna be a winner. The rest of the nose followed with some wood, grass, citrus and yeast. The flavors were absolutely delicious and smooth, with a ton of hops in the forefront. A woody and bready malt backbone provided plenty of support. I tasted plenty of herbs, spices, wood, some citrus and caramel malt. This has to be one of the best Oktoberfest beers on the market!

12 oz bottle from Milk and Hops Chelsea. Clear caramel / amber pour with a beige head and medium lacing. Heavy malty aroma and flavor. Rye bread, earth, maple/cedar type tree bark thing, and some hop dryness. Tingly feel. Decent enough, but not really better than that for me.
Tap @ Top Hops. Pours clear amber with an off white head. Aromas and flavours of bread, caramel, wood, pine and fruit. Medium body. Very fresh. Great stuff.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color. No head. Very malty . Standard marten. Good for the season

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Mild malty beer, a little high on the alcohol side. Woodsy, grains, rye -- all good flavors, but just a bit too heavy on the tongue.
12oz bottle from the bottle. Dark brown color. Lots of malt and some medium hop bitterness.

Bottle from Boise Co-op. Medium amber pour with thick off white head. Looks good. Light malty aroma, malts come through a bit stronger in the taste, caramel, S mall bitter finish.j. Good, but Top 50, I dont think do.

Bottle. Pours clear deep orange, medium creamy beige head, good lacing. Aroma is super malty, Bready, nutty, caramel, a bit woody. Socks is medium sweet, light plus bitter, malty, rye spiciness. Medium body, soft mouthfeel. Pretty solid beer.

There are some strong opinions about this. Its definitely interesting. Bright, hoppy aroma, like an imperial red, which matches the color. The flavor has some obvious malt balance, and for a while I was inclined to it. But there are some off notes, too, and a bitter intensity that didnt suit me. Ok though. Bottle.

This draft brew from a restaurant poured a head of foamy white colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a no visible carbonation semi-opaque light brown colored body and a fair lacing. The nice aroma was malty. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish malty aftertaste. The nice flavor contained notes of mild hops and malt. A decent one that I would consider drinking again.

Pours a clear medium amber with an off white thin head. Malty aroma. Lightly syrupy body. Caramel and malt sweet taste with some light spices. Not very refreshing or enjoyable. Too sweet for my liking.

Rich amber/cider color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, caramel, floral hops, some fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet roasted malt, caramel, herbal hops, fruit, and spice; Finish is fairly bitter; A bit too hoppy for the style - but decent overall.

12 oz 2016 bottle.
Clear copper body with a short head with poor retention and limited lacing. 
This is a rather hoppy version of the style, with mild bitterness rather than light sweetness.

Solid beer. A strong version of a marzen. More hoppy than expected. Highly carbonated with a solid head. Slight nutty 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This beer if either a) its all you have or b) you are a Lagunitas fanboi who believes that everything they make, no matter how horrid, is incredible. 

This stuff looks like beer and comes in a beer bottle, but it tastes like stale french fries. It has a grease foretaste that masks any potentially decent aftertaste. 

All the other reviews of this stuff -- yknow, the ones that dont mention its awful taste -- are simply wrong. 

So many great beers to choose from. Even from Lagunitas (which is overrated). This stuff is not that. Avoid. Avoid. Avoid.

Drank this after 3 Brooklyn black chocolate stouts, while warming up my potato skins in my toaster oven. See pic: 
 http://i.imgur.com/H37bHOS.png 

Pours Amber. Aroma of flowers smothered in dirt. Taste is hot dogs with sugar. Meh. Sweet. Cloying. This is horrific.

On tap. Pours a mahogany color with a big head and good lacing. Aroma of toasty malt, bit of caramel and grain. Taste is similar to the aroma. Nice bitterness and a clean finish. Medium body, crisp and clean. Nice way to start the seasonal beers.

Aroma is caramel malt, somewhat fruity, earthy hops, bready, sweet, corn. Appearance is reddish brown, off white head, clear. Taste is earthy hops, fruity, caramel, bread, malt, actually very tasty. Mouthfeel is light to medium body, light crisp carbonation, fruity bready aftertaste. Overall, this is probably the best Oktoberfest Ive ever had.

Malty aroma with dank hops and an unexpected salty bacon-like characteristic to it. Amber color with a significant tuft of off white foam. The taste also has some bacon to it, almost a smoked quality. Malty flavor, the hops do not show up, I was wanting more in that aspect, definitely surprising for a Lagunitas beer. The palate is more carbonated than a traditional Oktoberfest. This was odd. Im glad I bought a single bottle and not a six pack.

Draught @ Milk and Hops - Chelsea. Clear dark copper with small creamy beige head, faint pumpkin-caramel aroma, medium carbonation, sweetish starting pumpkin taste, followed by bitter caramel flavor, smooth body, long medium bitter finish with slight caramel aftertaste. Very nice pumpkin ale.
Bottle sample at Hy-Vee Oktoberfest. Poured copper, white head. Aroma was toasted malts, caramel, wood. Taste was bittersweet, nutty, caramel malt.

Malty goodness here. Lagunitas is as good as a bigger brewer can hope to be with such a diverse lineup. 
Lots of Malts. Aroma is of a little caramel. Flavor is brown sugar, maple syrup, cloves, raisins, grapes, etc

Bottle into pils glass, bubbly clear deep amber color with tan head. Aroma notes of faint fruity (white grape?) hops, caramel malt and distant earthy/herbal notes. Taste adds grapefruit juice, toast, some pine and candy fruity zest. Light-medium body, moderate-heavy carbonation, crisp, tad dry with light lingering fruity caramel finish. Most fruity Octoberfest Ive had to date.
On draft at Pizzaeria Paradiso in Old Town. Pours a clear amber with an ecru head. Malty nose. Flavors of peach and orange. Very tasty.

12oz bottle from Total Wine in Reno 
Pours clear amber with a small off-white head, good lacing. Aroma is earthy, mild bisquity and herbal. Flavor of pine, herbal, bready and grassy 
Good
Bottled 7.5% from Casa De Oro. Good and malty up front with a little sweetness. Some earthy qualities to it as well. Pretty drinkable octo, but nothing to great.

Tallahassee, Fl. - on tap at Momos Northside. Sparkling dark copper pour, nice off-white head with thick lacing. Aroma of white grapes and dates. Flavor presents some molasses, ripening vegetables, cotton candy, an off vinegar-like twang. Decent thickness to the mouthfeel.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a caramel color followed by tan head. Marzen malt meet Lagunitas hop oil. Nothing wrong with a different take on the American version of the style.
UPDATED: OCT 13, 2016 This beer tastes like ass mixed with Durian.  I love durian, but it should not be in beer.
Pours a clear copper color. Huge white head that lasts with tons of sticky lacing. Malty but bright hop aroma. Tastes as if a bright hoppy IPA was blended with scotch ale.
Poured from the bottle. Thin head aroma is malty, colour is dark copper. Flavour is slightly sweet but there is a nice hint of hop bitterness. This doesnt have the normal lager distinct flavor.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a thick off-white head. Aromas of sweet caramel and herbal hops. Flavors are toasted caramel, oak, biscuit, and herbal hops. Sweet, roasty-toasty flavors. Rich and malty. Creamy mouthfeel. Very nice.

Sampled at the Great American Beer Festival 2016, Denver, CO.
Clear copper golden color with a small white head. 
Malty and hoppy. Really IPA like Märzen. Very drinkable. More Oktoberfest brews like this please.

this Lager lacks the usual bite I enjoy from an IPA but as far as Lagers go I like it quite a bit. It is dark coper/red in color with a very off white head that stays. 
To me it is a beautiful beer that I would order again

12 oz. bottle. Thank you Brian for the share. Color is a crystal clear Amber orange color. Aroma is toffee, herbal like hops, weak yeast. 
Slightly elevated hop profile in what wants to be a Marzen beer. Decent malt backbone. No flaws, nothing wrong with it just plain and ordinary. Not sure what all the hype is maybe a little group think?
12oz bottle from CBC. Pours amber with an off white head. Aroma is caramel, fruity esters, pine, herbal. Flavor is caramel, fruity esters, cedar.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2016 Draft at Moriartys. Clear deep amber pour. Lots of beige foam. Mild aroma. Medium caramel bready malts. Candied orange peels. Some nuttiness. Solid but not overly complex.

12 oz. bottle indicates 7.5% abv. Pours clear orange-copper with a lasting disc of beady foam. Nose is big with toffee, spicy resin, tea leaf, citrus zest and a touch of toasted nut. Flavors of orange toffee, grassy-wooden hops and toasted nut. Medium-plus body has a smooth, low-medium carbonation and a nice balance. Just a hint of the abv.

Malty ass scent up front followed by nice sweet sugary smells. Nice clear amber color with one finger head nice lacing. Real nice sweet maltiness throughout the whole flavor that thends to linger on the tougue it seems like forever, awesome taste. Medium body with righteous carbonation. Best octoberfest brew that Ive had to date. Freakin awesome brew you guy did it just right to start this October off right.

Spännande öl ganska speciell doft och smak. Maltig, lite sötma, lite humlighet. Duglig men ingen hit. @sbwf16

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Personally I prefer more traditional Oktoberfeststyle. So this one takes a hit for being a bit hoppy. Its good but it in an odd sort of way.

Bottle-Pours deep copper hue with a very small fizzy eggshell head and barely any lacing. Nose is big hops, mushy grains, seems a bit unbalanced for sure. I guess thats the nature of the beast with a hoppy beer of this style. Flavors are somewhat muddled and nothing really descript-bright hops, mushy malts, seems unbalanced and a tad on the sweet side. Maybe a hint of alcohol as well. Finish is sweet malty with lingering notes of toasted grains, citric hops and some faint cereal. An ok beer but definitely doesnt go all that well in terms of being a hoppy lager.

Brewed in the vein of Surlys SurlyFest, Tuberfest brings American hops to an old German style. I like the results because, well, I cant even help it. This beer has a copper hue and long-lasting head plus an impressive amount of lacing. Definitely a hop-forward aroma with earthy, woodsy, and spicy notes. The pungent nose creates a different expectation for the flavor. The taste is actually quite balanced. Brown sugar, toffee, light chocolate, nuts, and toasted bread for the malt profile. Herbaceous and moderately bitter hops toward the end. Yes, its the hoppy approach youd expect from a Lagunitas brew, but the complexity is remarkable. Despite the current trend of adding more botanicals to any style you can name theres really nothing else out there thats like this.
Interesting aroma, burnt wood/sugar. Very good looking beer, taste is different but interesting -- woody.

Bottle from Meditrina. Clear dark copper with head and lace. LEafy hop and toasty malt aromas with hints of citrus and coffee. Light toasty caramel sweetness with a little fruitiness a very fresh citrus and woody leafy hops. Medium body and lively carbo accentuates hops. Not authentic but definitely tasty.

On tap Pours a hazed amber with a thick, off white color head. Aroma of earthy and herbal hops, toasted malt. Flavor is hop forward, medium bitterness. A study malt presence. Full bodied with a creamy texture. Finishes with a lingering bitterness

Sample at SBWF 2016. 

Amber with a small head. On the sweet side with caramel, malt and dark bread. The body was medium. A decent one.

An aroma I dont care for at all. Soapy. Even before seeing the general high rating, being a fan of Lagunitas I was disappointed in this. It has some hops as advertised in the back end, but theres something about the flavor that doesnt work at all for me. Maybe its just overpowered by my hatred of the aroma.

Dark red-amber and clear with a thick head and nice lace. Rich dried fruit and nut aroma, with maybe some molasses to bring it all together. Rich bitter-sweet flavor. Thick and velvety mouthfeel. Very good overall.

DATE: September 29, 2016... OCCASION: Thirsty Thursday again... GLASSWARE: crystal mug... dark amber, almost brown orange body with some turbulent bubbles rising... a two-finger white head sits strongly before thinning to a creamy, swirling head... first scents of rosewood, coriander, lemon, and a mega-powerful load of caramel... a medium-bodied sip that tickles the teeth and resounds at the throat... for 7.5%, an unbelievably agreeable lager whose consistency begs for immediate consumption... flavor is as promised, with the caramel and flowery wood empowering the pleasant experience... an Oktoberfest that is hopped up on the kinds of flavors that suggest an IPA... some phenolic alcohol hints, but the majority of flavor is sweet, robust and powerful... overall, what does one expect from Lagunitas? A hoppy approximation of what a fest might be, but wow, this is a beer that transcends genre... better if consumed while sitting for the evening...

Poured into a mug, the appearance was a ruddy dark orange somewhat leaning to hazy brown. Nice transparency. Thin white foamy lacing clings nicely all around the glass.
The aroma starts off with some sweet to bitter earthy, herbal, grassy, and piney hops. Oktoberfest levels of pure nutty/caramel/toffee sweetness slides in with enough balance to make sure the drinker knows that this is an Oktoberfest beer.
The flavor leans a balanced hoppy to malty sweet. Malty rich nutty and toffee/caramel aftertaste leads into a quick sweet finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a nice sessionable smooth feel to it. Low carbonation. Acceptable semi-stickiness.
Overall, this was a pretty good Oktoberfest that I could have again.

Pours caramel with a low white head. Aromas of caramel, rye bread, citrus, ripe apple, raisins, toffee. Taste is quite sweet with fruity, caramel and floral notes. Mouthfeel is light bodied with medium carbonation.

Bottle from Whole Foods Market in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is strong herbal, cedar, green onions, vegetal, floral, malty, earthy. Taste is sweet herbal earthy wet hops and malts. This has so much earthy and herbal depth of flavor with rich malts and vegetal hops... yet super balanced. A bouillon / marmalade of a beer. Not sure its a Märzen but Ill take it.

On the redder side for this somewhat style. Very pretty. Very nice hoppy nose. Mint coconut hops in a subtle pine base. Hints of mineral caramel Oktoberfest. Very hoppy flavor , pine, minty pine, and refined hops. Oktoberfest underneath of an imperial caliber. I wouldnt say cedary as much as I would say it has that vanilla/coconut oaky presence. Lagunitas are great composers of hops and creating the best of beers just like masters like Stone Brewing. Very consistant great beers, kings of beers. Whats cooler is a six pack isnt priced its worth, but they and we know its worth more, theyre just not dicks. They can do that being the best of the best though, and they are.
12 oz bottle from Hy-vee. Flavors I couldnt quite put my fingers on. Nice deep orange pour. Malty but not really marzen-like. More spicey, some cedar flavors, some cola. Sharp finish.

What am i smelling, weird mish-mash (are there potatoes in this) maybe Im smelling potatoesalcohol, resin, something fluffy. Tasting toasted sunflower seed, corn, alcohol & caramel. Solid on the palate, multi-dimensional finish.

Pours awesome. Nose is sweet. Sticky, old cookies, beer, sweet, light caramel. It's good to drink 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. It pours a clear dark golden amber color with a foamy off white head. The aroma is full with toasted malt and lighter hints of fruity grape and pineapple. The toasted malt takes the forefront though. Maybe a hint of floral and herbal hops. The flavor is bready and toasted up front followed by significant fruity hops. Grape, berries and pineapple stand out. Its pretty full bodied, but feels reasonably drinkable on the palate due to the toasted malt and lightly floral bitter finish. Overall, Im digging this beer way more than I thought I would. It comes across as more of a decent hoppy amber ale or even a hoppy bock. Oktoberfest seems like a stretch. I only bought one bottle for the tick, but Im pretty sure Ill spring for a sixer now that I know its a pretty tasty beer.

The beer pours clear copper with an off white head. The aroma has toasty make, cedar, spice, dry caramel and some floral hops. It has a medium/full body with fairly mild caramel. The taste has had spice, cedar, woodiness and dry malt. I guess this is technically a marzen, but comes across to me as a nice hop forward amber ale.

Bottle:
Clear copper with a tall, thick, beige head.
Caramel, cedar, breadheel aroma.
Taste is sweet, caramel malt, lightly spicy grain malt.....a good deal of cedar notes coming through....
Quite different, but good.
Not sure if Id call this a marzen or Oktoberfest, but its pretty good. These guys do a nice job with whatever they take on.

Beautiful appearance, appealing aroma, great flavor, and nice on the palate. Lagunitas Tuberfest is an excellent Oktoberfest-style beer that is malty with great hop flavor that is earthy and herbal. There is just enough alcohol present to balance the sweetness and luxurious mouthfeel of this beer. Lagunitas Tuberfest is really hitting the spot for me this year as it is different and not overly hoppy or bitter, but definitely rich and subtlety complex.

Clear copper color, moderate to large head, decent lace/retention. Aroma is toast, toffee, moderate hops. Medium bodied, very drinkable, the alcohol is hidden well. Its basically a Marzen with a moderate hop presence.

Poured from the six pack of bottles, clear brown with a lot of foam. This is a weird one for me because of expectations, I got sticky, gritty, sweet, a little burnt, and very dry at the end. I didnt get the signature Lagunitas hops I was expecting, but I didnt get anything close to an Oktoberfest either. It is 7.5% which is high for this style so Ill enjoy it for that, but its a confusing beer.

Pour into a hurricane glass, which generally amplifies the head. Couldnt squeeze 12 oz. into the 16 oz. glass. Big head which settles down to a persistent half-inch. Nice golden brown color. Aroma of caramel and hops. Light body, decent mouthfeel. The style you might expect, octoberfest marzen, is not what you get here (this is the case with other Lagunitas products as well), but taken as a unique brew this one is OK. Flavor is a bit of a mish-mash of caramel, pine, grain and some stewed vegetable like broccoli. Not unpleasant and not sweet with a mildly bitter aftertaste. Its easy drinking, but Im glad I bought one and not a sixer.

Pours clear copper with a nice, thick eggshell head. Aroma features woody hops, toasted malt, and not-so-subtle citrus tones. Flavor adds a little cedar and a bit of caramel to the mix for a wunderbar brew. Mouthfeel presents firm body and good fizz. Ach, dieses ist ein gutes Bier!

12 oz bottle pours a light brown color with a small white head. Aromas of sweet malt, caramel, light citrus. Light bodied, interesting take on an octoberfest

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Not sure I would drink it again. A little below average all the way around. Meh
Draft pour at Lagunitas taproom. White head. Very sweet. Candy malty corn and syrupy. Pretty good

Pours a thin head on a dark straw body.
Aroma is mild chocolate, cedar and caramel.
Taste is a malty and sweet, but not over the top. Dry finish.
Texture is medium.
Clear copper with tan head. Thin malt on both flavor and aroma. Herbs and grass in the flavor but not aroma. Mediocre.
Chewy grain with a little bit of fruity melon hops working. Surprisingly complementary and melding together well.

Cheap is gonna love this shit! Marzenlike in color and crispness, maybe hints of bead and the sweet malt bite, but more floral and lightly fruity and bitter hops than anything else. I enjoyed it, though I cant quite think of it as an Oktoberfest. Just a good hoppy lager.
Aroma is citrus hops, light tropical fruit and malts. The flavor is citrus, unique grainy malts, light tropical fruit and a bittersweet finish.

12 ounce bottle purchased from Romeys in Woodland. The aroma has some floral and earthy hop character, before some sweet, toffee like malts come through. I also get a little toasted malt character, too. Transparent copper colored body with a smallish off-white head present. Starts with a lightly metallic flavor, before this becomes full of toasted cereal malts. Sticky mouthfeel. Mild tinny hop flavor to finish. Easily, the maltiest beer I have had from Lagunitas. Pretty tasty.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a hazed amber with a thick, off white color head. Aroma of earthy and herbal hops, toasted malt. Flavor is hop forward, medium bitterness. A study malt presence. Full bodied with a creamy texture. Finishes with a lingering bitterness.
3rd of flight of 4 @ lagunitas chicago. nice clear tea color, somehow ended up with 3 brown beers, sweet, malty, didnt get potato.
Pours a clear copper golden with a short white head. Clean apricot nose. Astringent mouthfeel. Apricot and malted golden barley flavors. Easy drinking.
